title: Healthcare in Remote Areas
content: A missionary physician runs a hospital in the Nuba Mountains in Sudan, providing extraordinary work as the only doctor in a remote, war-torn region of Africa. In terms of individual lives saved, there is arguably no other person on the front lines doing more. The manner in which the Nuba people die is explored, which is in striking contrast to the ubiquity of chronic disease and self-harm in the west, despite the extreme poverty and unimaginable suffering experienced by the Nuba people.

title: Healthcare Challenges and Needs
content: The basic tools, technologies, and medicines that could save many lives are lacking. There are logistical challenges in helping the hospital, and what is really needed is discussed.

title: Diseases in Adult Population
content: Diseases in the adult population are discussed.

title: Living Conditions and Health
content: Living without possessions, finding meaning, and being a missionary are discussed. The sense of purpose, happiness, and suicide rates are contrasted between the US and Nuba.

title: Food and Health
content: The food in Nuba is discussed.

title: Malaria
content: The annual bout of malaria is discussed.

title: Memorable Patients
content: Patients that will never be forgotten are discussed.

title: Tom’s annual bout of malaria
content: Tom’s annual bout of malaria.

title: Supporting Mother of Mercy Hospital
content: You can directly support the needs of the Mother of Mercy Hospital by going to African Mission Healthcare donation page. The following are some of the most urgent needs: Operating eye microscope and associated supplies, Housing, Batteries for solar panels, Pay for a C-section.

title: Healthcare Staff and Services Before War
content: Before the war broke out, the hospital staff included 8 expats from Kenya and Uganda. Tom was the only doctor. There were a few nurses, anesthetists, and a lab person. Plus 15 local staff from Nuba who had to be taught literally everything.

title: Healthcare Challenges During War
content: Fighting begins in June 2011 after Southern Sudan votes to secede. A plane came, last plane for a long time, and staff had to decide whether to leave or stay. Tom stayed. All other expats left. So now just Tom and local Nuba people. The biggest problem was anesthesiology for surgery. The morning that the staff left, there was a bombing by the North Sudan’s air force. Mangled bodies start rolling in. Huge shards of metal tore through people creating massive tissue loss and trauma.

title: Medical Procedures During War
content: First case after staff evacuated was a girl needing her arm amputated. Neither Tom, nor the nurses knew how to do general anesthesia. They literally read a basic anesthesia book that listed it out step by step. Tom had to intubate the patient, which can kill them if done wrong, something Tom had never done before. Then someone had to manually ventilate the patient throughout the entire surgery. All they had was an Oxford Miniature Ventilator. They were without an anesthetist for 2 months. Tom can’t measure blood gasses (PaO2, PaCO2). He also had no pulse oximeter which measures the percentage of oxygen saturation.

title: Injuries from Shrapnel
content: Liver lacerations, bowel injuries, hemopneumothorax, head trauma, kidney trauma, etc. occur when shrapnel is going through people. One guy has 23 holes in his intestines that had to be resected and stitched.

title: Local Health Practices
content: Local traditions include burning to try to release fevers, malaria, and other illness, the local tradition is to burn the skin to release the illness. Some herbal remedies for malaria (not much evidence it is working). Local fruits and veggies for GI problems (works a little bit per Tom). Local shamans known as the Kujur, the shamans will visit the family and come up with a reason why a child may be sick (this unfortunately delays the time until they will see a real doctor).

title: Learning Surgery on the Job
content: Trained for internal medicine in a family practice so he had minimal surgical training. But when got to Kenya, he saw it as a necessity to learn, I realized a lot of the disease burden in Africa was surgically related. A ton of wound care, miscarriages, laparotomies, amputations. Like another residency learning from other doctors in Kenya.

title: Building Trust with Patients
content: Being a foreigner, there was definitely a trust barrier that needed to be overcome. In the early days, it was quite scary to think you could have a bad outcome with a patient. Now he is trusted so it is easier in that sense.

title: Dealing with Patient Death
content: How does Tom deal with telling families he can’t save someone? Nuba people have low expectations, they don’t expect miracles. They just want to be treated as a human, they want that human touch. As a people, they are very accepting of negative outcomes or bad news.

title: Healthcare in Nuba Mountains
content: The Nuba Mountains are a remote location where healthcare is a challenge. The hospital in the region has 435 beds and is always at 100% occupancy. At the peak of war, it would be 550 people there, just laying all over the ground. The hospital sees about 300 patients per day. The biggest problem is the logistics of getting the supplies. Supplies have to come from Nairobi which is 2 countries away. It takes weeks to get to Yida, South Sudan. Then its 6 hours dirt roads to get from Yida to Nuba. The hospital tries to make it one full year on that supply that gets sent in.

title: Maternal and Infant Mortality in Nuba Mountains
content: Infant mortality is still very high in the Nuba Mountains. Most neonatal deaths are just from difficult deliveries (baby gets asphyxiated, baby’s born and dies, either is a stillborn, or dies soon after birth). 99% of women there still deliver at home, but many of the infant deaths would have survived with a c-section. The mortality of mothers is unknown. It’s likely pretty high because there are a lot of women that end up doing C-sections that would have died without that.

title: Learning Surgery on YouTube
content: In the Nuba Mountains, there is a lack of medical training resources. As a result, surgeries are sometimes learned from YouTube. For example, a partial nephrectomy (removing part of a kidney because of a tumor) was performed successfully after watching a YouTube video.

title: Challenges of Healthcare in Remote Locations
content: In remote locations like the Nuba Mountains, healthcare providers face numerous challenges. For example, during a measles epidemic, 225 kids per day were seen on top of everything else. Vaccines couldn't be delivered to Nuba because they were in rebel-territory. The physical and mental exhaustion and emotional trauma of always being on call and responsible for the patients is very draining.

title: Lack of Basic Tools, Technologies, and Medicines
content: In the Nuba Mountains, there is a lack of basic tools, technologies, and medicines that could save many lives. The hospital has an ultrasound and an x-ray machine, but the biggest challenge is lab work. The machines keep breaking down. Acute leukemia in children can't be treated with chemotherapy and they basically help them with palliative care (end of life care). Chronic myelocytic leukemia (CML) is very treatable with the drug called Gleevec, but it's too expensive yet it would cure almost all cases of CML. It costs $7,000 per month.

title: Logistical Challenge of Helping Nuba Hospital
content: Helping the hospital in the Nuba Mountains is a logistical challenge. Money is half the battle, the other half is logistics. The first step is to contact the Catholic Medical Mission Board (CMMB). For example, if someone were to send Gleevec to CMMB, and they could find a way to get it to Juba, then they might be able to find a way to get it to Tom in Nuba.

title: Prevalent Diseases
content: Liver disease is high on the list, including cirrhosis and liver cancers, mostly from hepatitis B. Hepatitis B is very common. Diphtheria, which hasn't been seen since the 1940s in the US, shows up in Africa due to lack of vaccines. Leprosy, in the tuberculosis family, is transmitted by respiratory droplets and prolonged close contact. Tuberculosis is very prevalent. HIV is actually quite low, less than 1%. STDs are common, including gonorrhea and syphilis.

title: Heart Disease and Obesity
content: Congestive heart failure is seen in people in their 60s & 70s, not atherosclerotic in origin. Obesity is almost non-existent. Type 2 Diabetes is rare, but it is seen in some people in the 50s. Fatty liver disease is never seen.

title: Cancers in Nuba
content: Common cancers in Nuba include Burkitt’s lymphoma in kids, which is common in areas with malaria. In adults, liver cancer is most common, probably all related to hepatitis B positivity. Cervical cancer in women is common, but pap smears to screen for HPV are impractical. Breast cancer cases exist, but people are only diagnosed when they come in with a noticeable lump. Colon cancer is very rare.

title: Average Lifespan and Cognitive Impairment
content: The average lifespan is guessed to be not much longer than 70s. Cognitive impairment is really rare, as people probably die of something else before they reach that stage.

title: Suicide Rates
content: Cases of suicide in Nuba are extremely rare. In the US, suicide is among the top 10 causes of death in every age demographic except for 0 to 10. When you include the ‘slow suicide’, when people that kill themselves with alcohol and drugs over time, it is actually in the top-five causes of death across the board.

title: Food in Nuba
content: The food in Nuba has very little variety. A common dish is Asida, a cake made out of sorghum, totally tasteless. Usually, people eat rice, kidney beans, some kind of lentils, and once in a while, chicken. The sorghum actually has a high protein level. Fruits and veggies are seasonal, including mangoes, lemons, and tomatoes.

title: Malaria Symptoms and Effects
content: Malaria symptoms include: real bad headache, nausea, vomiting, inability to sleep, high fevers, and terrible body aches. A lot of times, it’ll drag on for a month. Severe cases can even lead to coma.

title: Health Consequences of Bombing
content: Bomb shrapnel can lead to severe infections if not properly cleaned. Victims can also develop trauma from the experience. Napalm bombs can cause third-degree burns on a large percentage of the body, leading to agonizing pain and often death.

title: Burn Victims
content: Burns can be caused by various incidents, such as a straw structure catching fire and falling into a foxhole. Severe burns over 80% of the body, referred to as 'full thickness', can be fatal.

title: Gunshot Wounds
content: Gunshot wounds can be fatal, especially when they occur in the head. Even if the victim survives initially, complications can arise leading to death.

title: Importance of Individual Care in Medicine
content: In the end, medicine is individual. It’s the beauty of our profession. And it’s a huge privilege to have the opportunity to affect one person. And in the end, you close the door and it’s you and the patient, whether you’re in Nuba mountains, whether you’re here in New York. And that’s an incredible privilege. And I think if we keep that focus, just one person at a time, I think people can kind of relax a bit. You can see that what you’re doing for that one person. . .I think people look at Africa and say, “What you’re doing is a drop in the ocean.” I really like that story because when you’re there, you don’t see a drop in the ocean. You see a person. You see a life. And you see somebody that can laugh, and can cry, and can play, has aspirations, and is a living, breathing human being. You think, “Man, we helped this one person.” That’s a huge thing, you know? But I think that helps to stave off some of the burnout and the cynicism. This is a very individual thing, so one person is really a big deal. It’s everything to that one person, that one person’s family. And I think we really have to keep that in mind, especially with this growing realm of cynicism and sort of negativity that we see now.
